captions.text: I&#39;ve got a new book available on Audible.com from December 9th
It&#39;s called Existentially Challenged
and it&#39;s a hilarous supernatural murder mystery
set in a world getting to grips with the british government
having declassifed the existance of magic.
To answer all of the anticipated questions
Yes, it&#39;s a sequel to Differently Morphous.
Yes, it&#39;s only an audiobook at the moment.
Yes, it&#39;s read by me.
Yes, a print verison will be out next year sometime.
And no, I don&#39;t still wear this hat in real life.
*INTRO MUSIC*
&quot;Shin Megami Tensei, Yahtzee!&quot;
Er. Sorry, I haven&#39;t got any tissues.
&quot;No! You big racist.
You should play the new Shin Megami Tensei V
since you like Persona games so much.&quot;
Went the anime fans every bloody week for the last month.
For fuck&#39;s sake, you anime fans are like drug dealers, you are.
You hang around outside middle schools looking for any kid
showing the slightest interest in Pokemon cards
and then refuse to leave them alone until they&#39;re gluing fridge
magnets to their hair and insisting on being called Sasuke.
&quot;Shin Megami Tensei is the mainline series of RPGs that Persona
spun off from, Yahtzee, as you bloody well know you constantly
Evangelion-referencing obvious closet anime liking person.
Shin Megami Tensei basically is Persona without the day to day life
sim aspect or vibrant visual design or really good music or
engaging characters that make it constant fodder for cultural
reference, anime adaptation and fanmade jailbait pornography.&quot;
That was rather a tangential sales pitch, and not exactly an
effective one.
&quot;It&#39;s Persona without any of the shit you like about Persona.&quot;
&quot;Alright how about this one? Your Halo Infinite code hasn&#39;t come in
yet and you&#39;ve got a week to fill before Christmas.&quot;
Oh bollocks. Whatever.
It&#39;s true, Persona is a spinoff from the longrunning Shin Megami
Tensei series, a spinoff with better art, funkier music,
more engaging story and deeper gameplay design.
Bloody hell. If I had a wart on my bum, apparently Atlus would
refer to me as Yahtzee the popular wart spinoff.
But if there&#39;s one thing gatekeepery shitheads always bring up
when comparing the two it&#39;s that the Shinguard Marmite Fantasy
games are the anime RPGs for REAL men.
Who ain&#39;t got time for all that kissy-poo befriending super nice
girlies with obvious personal issues and a thing for tall quiet boys
with appalling time management skills
they wanna really get to grips with the meat of the RPG combat
and the technical challenge of assembling and training the most
effective team of personas. I mean, demons.
Sorry, I get confused because they work exactly the same way
as personas and have the same names and use the same art
assets. The point is, Persona&#39;s never really leant into the combat
challenge and if you halfway know what you&#39;re doing you can beat
most of its boss fights in normal mode pretty easily by constantly
slapping your willy against the Rakunda button.
That was definitely not my experience with Shin Megami Tenseiv.
Whose boss fights would usually immediately pound me through
the garden fence and force me to go back and grind up demons
with abilities and defenses that counter the elemental strengths
and weaknesses of the boss, which I of course had no conceivable
way of knowing without allowing myself to be thinly sliced and
packaged for sandwiches at least once, which doesn&#39;t make a
whole lot of sense in context but it&#39;s challenge that counts and
context is for chumps.
But let&#39;s stop reading ahead and get back to how the game starts.
You play as mute emotionally dead androgynous teenage anime
protagonist du jour who goes to a high school in Tokyo whose
uniform I think is supposed to look like it&#39;s decorated with white
blossoms but looks more like the entire student body had to run
through a crowded henhouse on the way here.
You&#39;re minding your mute androgynous business one day when you
get mysteriously transported to an alternative version of Tokyo that
looks like Godzilla finally decided to stop putting up with its bullshit.
Almost immediately you meet a magic man for some reason and
the two of you combine somehow into a sword-wielding hero with
a luscious flowing hairdo even though both of you had short hair.
It turns out the Tokyo you were living in was a copy or something
to replace the original after it got infested by demon immigrants
and slipped into an evil netherworld like some kind of magical
Japanese Los Angeles.
Anyway, you have to help fight the eternal conflict between God
and Satan because the Japanese prime minister said so and telling
him to go eternal conflict himself wasn&#39;t a dialog option.
Well, at least we get stuck into the action a lot faster than in
Persona, where there&#39;s typically about twelve in-game days and at
least one juicy murder before they&#39;ll let you in the tutorial dungeon,
but in all that faffing about it&#39;s establishing characters and getting
you engaged with the plot, and that&#39;s just not happening for me in
Saturday Morning Television because the plot feels so lofty and
emotionless and our high school protagonist isn&#39;t much use as
a fish out of water viewpoint character because they&#39;ve got all
the personality and backstory of a used tea towel.
The backstory of most tea towels being &quot;I bought it from a tea
towel shop.&quot;
Then you look to all the other high schooler characters that got
introduced alongside you and they&#39;re all like &quot;Don&#39;t look at me,
I was secretly part of the God/Satan war this whole time and I&#39;ve
got unexplained superpowers, I&#39;m not the least bit relatable either.&quot;
And what also hurts the plot is that there&#39;s such large gaps
between story developments.
Once you&#39;re teleported to post-COVID Tokyo at the start of
the game you&#39;re stuck there rubbing perdemonas together for four
or five hours before you beat the first handful of bosses and get
back to real Tokyo to get the theological conflict thing established
and sworn into the Bible Brigade, and by that point I could barely
remember what my original haircut had looked like.
Although I did feel a stir of emotional connection when I first ran
out into bad Tokyo and encountered a Pixie.
It was a much needed pang of familiarity in a strange place.
Instantly I knew a long and complicated ladder of Desonmon
crafting lay ahead. No doubt we&#39;ll see all our old friends, Jack Frost,
Neko Shogun, that one that looks hauntingly like a penis,
but it always starts with Pixie.
The first acorn that starts the spreading oak.
The first vaccine hesitant parent that starts the downfall of Western
civilization. And if there&#39;s any part of Megaman&#39;s Shiny Testicles
that I feel I could get into it&#39;s the demon collectathon aspect.
You have little conversations with them in battle and pick the right
dialog options to convince them to join you, and it has a quirk and
humour to it that feels rather out of place alongside all the
glowering twats in the main plot.
Looks like we found where all the personality was hiding.
Fuck those humourless real world losers, let&#39;s gather together a
posse of hauntingly penis-like monsters and go give them all
wedgies. But the meat and potatoes of hunting demons in the
overworld is drowned in the watery onion gravy of dreary,
confusingly laid out environments.
Listen, thank you for your recommendation, anime twats, but the
fact is, I don&#39;t bring any enthusiasm to JRPGs because I don&#39;t
generally like samey turn-based battling, so the game has to meet
me halfway.
That&#39;s how my chemistry with Persona games always works,
there&#39;s enough energy on its part to compensate for my dowdy
arse.
Shin Megami Tensei just doesn&#39;t have that.
Our blind date ends with me pushing my peas around my plate as
it asks if I&#39;ve accepted Jesus into my heart.
But hey, if you prefer it for its meatier tactical challenge then good
for you. Some people like that. Some people like bringing their
guitar to parties and seething with resentment when everyone else
would rather play Rock Band than listen to them strumming out
Wish You Were Here by Pink Floyd for the fourteenth fucking time.
*OUTRO MUSIC
This video was made possible by...
